At midnight, competitors race up 60-foot bamboo towers covered with buns (the Bun Scrambling Competition). The festival originated during the Qing Dynasty when a plague was driven away by parading Pak Tai's image.

name: Lollapalooza
desc: Massive four-day music festival in Grant Park featuring 170+ acts across Chicago's stunning lakefront.
details: Taking over Grant Park with the Chicago skyline as a backdrop, Lollapalooza features 170+ artists across 8 stages over 4 days. Originally a touring festival founded by Jane's Addiction's Perry Farrell, it found a permanent home in Chicago and has become one of the city's defining cultural events, drawing fans from across the globe.

name: Palo Volador (Flying Pole Dance)
desc: Stunning pre-Hispanic Mayan ritual where costumed dancers spin downward from a 98-foot wooden pole on ropes, connected to ancient concepts of renewal and cosmic balance.
details: The Palo Volador is a breathtaking ceremonial dance where two pairs of flyers dressed in vivid traditional costumes climb a towering pole, then spin downward on ropes while striking various poses mid-air as the ropes gradually lower them to the ground. The ritual connects to pre-Hispanic Mayan spiritual beliefs about renewal and the cyclical nature of life. After communities choose the best tree to serve as the pole, it is dragged into the city, consecrated, and planted in a deep pit near the church. The performance is accompanied by marimba music during patronal festivities in the departments of Quiché and Baja Verapaz. The spectacle typically lasts several hours as the dancers complete their aerial descent.

name: Qoyllur Rit'i (Star Snow Festival)
desc: Sacred mountain glacier pilgrimage celebrating the reappearance of the Pleiades constellation, blending Catholic and Andean spiritual traditions at 4,600+ meters altitude.
details: This syncretic festival honors the return of the Pleiades (Qullqa in Quechua, meaning "Storehouse"), signifying the upcoming harvest and Andean New Year. Around 100,000 pilgrims trek to Sinakara Valley beneath Mount Ausangate, one of the most sacred Andean peaks. The festival combines Catholic devotion with indigenous worship, featuring night vigils, offerings, and dawn ceremonies as pilgrims gather beneath star-filled skies in the thin mountain air. Traditional music, dancing, and ritual performances accompany spiritual practices honoring both Christian and Andean deities.

name: Mazu Pilgrimage (Dajia Mazu)
desc: One of the world's largest religious pilgrimages—300km procession of the sea goddess Mazu across Taiwan.
details: The Dajia Mazu Pilgrimage is one of the world's three largest religious processions, alongside the Hajj and the Camino de Santiago. Over nine days, the statue of sea goddess Mazu is carried 300km from Dajia to Xingang and back. Millions line the route to pray, set off firecrackers, and offer food and drink to pilgrims. The procession runs 24 hours a day with elaborate temple ceremonies at each stop.

name: Edinburgh Festival Fringe
desc: The world's largest arts festival — a three-week explosion of 3,000+ shows across hundreds of venues in comedy, theater, dance, music, and every form of creative expression imaginable.
details: For three weeks in August, Edinburgh becomes the global capital of performing arts. Over 3,000 shows across hundreds of venues — from grand theaters to tiny closets — feature comedy, theater, dance, circus, cabaret, musicals, opera, music, and spoken word. The entirely open-access model means anyone with a story can perform. Past discoveries include Phoebe Waller-Bridge and countless comedy legends. The whole city buzzes from morning to late night.

name: Fes Festival of World Sacred Music
desc: Morocco's premier sacred music gathering showcasing diverse spiritual traditions across 11 centuries.
details: Founded in 1994, this internationally recognized festival brings together Sufi chanting, Andalusian orchestras, gospel choirs, Quranic recitations, and global sacred music traditions in Fes's most magical spaces—palaces, gardens, and ancient courtyards. It promotes religious tolerance and cultural diversity, attracting scholars, musicians, and spiritual seekers from around the world. Nearly three decades old, it remains one of Morocco's most intimate and spiritual cultural experiences.

name: Scoppio del Carro (Explosion of the Cart)
desc: An ancient Easter spectacle where a centuries-old cart explodes with fireworks in front of Florence's Duomo, launched by a mechanical dove flying along a wire from the altar.
details: Dating back to the First Crusade, this Easter Sunday tradition sees an ornate historical cart (Brindellone) pulled by white oxen to the Piazza del Duomo. During Easter Mass, a dove-shaped rocket (Colombina) flies along a wire from the Cathedral's high altar to ignite the cart's fireworks in a spectacular explosion. A successful ignition is believed to bring a good harvest and prosperity to the city.

name: Festival Internacional Cervantino (FIC)
desc: Latin America's foremost international arts festival, featuring theater, music, dance, and opera in a UNESCO World Heritage colonial city.
details: The 2026 edition welcomes 3,458 artists from 32 countries, with France as the guest of honor. Features prestigious international companies, innovative multimedia proposals, urban interventions, film screenings, and science presentations. 50% of presentations are free, bringing diverse artistic expressions to the public. Venues include Teatro Juárez, Alhóndiga de Granaditas esplanade, and main squares throughout the winding alleys of Guanajuato's colonial city.

name: Carnaval Huancayo (Central Highlands Carnival)
desc: Carnival celebration at 3,271 meters altitude blending vibrant street celebrations with ancient Andean traditions, water games symbolizing purification and renewal.
details: The Ño Carnavalón 2026 procession originates at Mariscal Castilla stadium, travels through Calle Real to Parque Huamanmarca, with approximately 70 delegations participating. Over 20 groups registered in the initial call. The festival features competitive elements judged by cultural directors. Playful water and foam use symbolizes cleansing and renewal, inviting participation in shared joy connecting to Andean fertility rituals. The high altitude (10,732 feet) affects physical demands on visitors.

name: Fiesta de San Juan (Saint John Festival)
desc: Amazon's most significant celebration honoring Saint John the Baptist, the patron saint of the rainforest, featuring bonfires, blessed baths, and traditional jungle music.
details: Festivities begin June 22-23 with prior events, gastronomic fairs, and sporting contests, plus the traditional "night of vigil." The central date is Wednesday, June 24. The Bonfire of San Juan symbolizes purification and renewal—locals believe jumping over the fire brings good health, prosperity, and protection. Men and women participate in the "blessed bath" in waterways on June 23 to receive blessings for a happy and healthy year. Traditional dishes include Patarashca (fish wrapped in banana leaves and cooked over fire) and Juanes (rice tamales with chicken, egg, and olives), the most representative foods of the holiday.

name: Greenwich Village Halloween Parade
desc: The nation's largest public Halloween parade, a spectacular procession of giant puppets, dancers, and costumed revelers through Greenwich Village.
details: Every Halloween night, Sixth Avenue in Greenwich Village becomes a river of costumed creativity as 50,000 participants and 2 million spectators enjoy this uniquely New York spectacle. Giant puppets, elaborate costumes, marching bands, and performance groups create an unforgettable night of public art and revelry.

name: 2026 Whitney Biennial
desc: The 82nd edition of the longest-running survey of contemporary art in the US, featuring 56 artists curated by Marcela Guerrero and Drew Sawyer.
details: The Whitney Biennial at the Whitney Museum of American Art features 56 artists, duos, and collectives. Curated by Marcela Guerrero and Drew Sawyer, this untitled edition foregrounds mood and texture. Notable participants include Andrea Fraser, Precious Okoyomon, and Julio Torres. First edition with expanded free admission for visitors 25 and under. Includes three Palestinian artists.

name: Día de Muertos - Oaxaca 2026
desc: Mexico's most authentic Day of the Dead celebration with family altar vigils, comparsa parades, and cemetery visits in villages like Xoxocotlán.
details: Oaxaca's Day of the Dead remains deeply rooted in indigenous tradition. Families build elaborate ofrendas with photos, marigolds, candles, and favorite foods. Nighttime cemetery vigils in villages like Xoxocotlán and Etla feature families sitting with candles among graves. Comparsa parades with painted-face revelers dance through city streets. The tradition reflects a worldview where death is celebrated as a continuation of life.

name: Carnaval de Oruro (unesco Masterpiece)
desc: One of UNESCO's Masterpieces of Oral and Intangible Heritage featuring 28,000 dancers in a 20-hour uninterrupted pilgrimage parade with 48 folk dance groups performing 18 traditional dances.
details: More than 48 groups of folk dancers specializing in 18 different folk dances perform a pilgrimage to the Shrine of the Tunnel (Santuario del Socavón) along Avenida Cívica. The festival blends indigenous celebration with Christian ritual around the Virgin of Socavón. The 20-hour Entrada features an uninterrupted parade with elaborate costumes, music, and traditional dances. Hotels and seating in Oruro sell out months in advance; many visitors base themselves in La Paz and visit as a day trip or multi-day package with reserved seating.

name: Carnaval de Oruro (unesco Masterpiece of Intangible Heritage)
desc: Bolivia's most important festival and a UNESCO Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity, featuring over 48 dance groups performing 18 distinct traditional dances including the iconic Diablada.
details: The Carnaval de Oruro takes place February 7-17, 2026, with the main pilgrimage and parade on Saturday, February 14, and celebrations continuing through Fat Tuesday, February 17. The Grand Pilgrimage to Socavón occurs on February 14, with the Entrada al Corso on Sunday, February 15. More than 48 groups perform 18 distinct dances, from the Diablada to the Morenada and Caporales, across a multi-day ritual ending at the Santuario del Socavón. On May 18, 2001, UNESCO proclaimed the Carnival one of the Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity. UNESCO inscribed Oruro's Carnival on its Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity. Local organizers promote 2026 under the phrase "La obra maestra que vive en ti," acknowledging the UNESCO "masterpiece" designation and the personal devotion behind every costume. The Spanish banned these ceremonies in the seventeenth century, but they continued under Christian liturgy guise, with the traditional diablada (worship of Andean deity Tiw) becoming the main Carnival dance. The celebration involves thousands of dancers, musicians, and artists, with the city receiving thousands of visitors; hotel occupancy reaches nearly 100%, so advance reservations are essential.

name: Festival de Cumbre Tajín
desc: Festival of identity at the ancient Totonac city of El Tajín, blending pre-Hispanic traditions with contemporary arts.
details: The 2026 edition runs only 3 days (shorter than previous 5-day versions) at three main venues: Parque Takilhsukut, El Tajín archaeological zone, and Papantla de Olarte. Most cultural and artistic activities are free at Takilhsukut Thematic Park and alternative venues. The festival transforms Papantla and the archaeological zone into the cultural epicenter of Veracruz, celebrating indigenous traditions, pre-Hispanic art, and contemporary culture.

name: Keti Koti (Emancipation Day)
desc: A national public holiday marking the day in 1863 when slavery was officially abolished in Suriname and the entire Dutch Empire.
details: Keti Koti means "The Chains have been cut!" This important national holiday commemorates the abolition of slavery in Suriname. Banks, government offices, and most businesses close for the holiday. The celebration includes parades, festivals, and cultural activities throughout the country honoring those who were enslaved and celebrating freedom.

name: Bastille Day (Fête Nationale)
desc: France's national day featuring the spectacular military parade on the Champs-Élysées, fighter jet flyovers, and a massive fireworks display at the Eiffel Tower.
details: July 14 commemorates the storming of the Bastille in 1789. The day begins with Europe's oldest and largest military parade along the Champs-Élysées, featuring the French Foreign Legion, cavalry, armored vehicles, and a fighter-jet flyover painting the sky in tricolor. The evening culminates with a massive fireworks display launched from the Eiffel Tower, watched by hundreds of thousands. Nationwide celebrations include open-air balls (bals des pompiers) at fire stations.

name: Spring Festival (Chinese New Year)
desc: The world's largest annual human migration and celebration marking the Lunar New Year with fireworks, dragon dances, and family reunions.
details: Chinese New Year is the most important holiday in China, triggering the world's largest annual human migration as hundreds of millions travel home. The 2026 Spring Festival begins Feb 17 (Year of the Horse) with a record 9-day official holiday. Celebrations include spectacular fireworks, lion and dragon dances, temple fairs, red envelope gift-giving, and reunion dinners. Major cities like Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou host massive public celebrations.

name: Bumba Meu Boi (São Luís, Maranhão)
desc: UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage festival combining folklore, music, dance, and theater celebrating the death and resurrection of a sacred ox with African, indigenous, and Portuguese influences.
details: The festival season begins Holy Saturday with rehearsals extending through mid-June. June 23 (eve of St. John's Day) marks the traditional baptism of the Oxen in a Catholic ritual granting permission to perform. Performances continue through late June and early July. Groups gather at the Chapel of São Pedro (June 29) and São Marçal Avenue (June 30). A fairground at Nauro Machado square in the tourist district features a stage with Friday and Saturday night performances. UNESCO recognized the Bumba Meu Boi Cultural Complex of Maranhão as Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity in 2019.

name: Tallinn Music Week
desc: The largest indoor music festival in the Nordic-Baltic region featuring nearly 200 artists across Tallinn's clubs and venues.
details: Tallinn Music Week is a major showcase festival and conference that introduces new music across genres. About 25,000 people attend events at the city's most important clubs and concert venues. The programme also includes TMW Tastes restaurant festival, TMW Art contemporary art programme, and TMW Stories talk series.

name: 61st Venice Biennale - In Minor Keys
desc: The world's most prestigious contemporary art exhibition, titled 'In Minor Keys,' realizes the curatorial vision of Koyo Kouoh who passed away during production.
details: The 61st International Art Exhibition runs May 9 to November 22, 2026, at the Arsenale and Giardini. Swiss-Cameroonian curator Koyo Kouoh, the first African woman to lead the event, passed away in May 2025. Her vision will be realized by the curatorial team she assembled. The exhibition title 'In Minor Keys' reflects her conceptual framework. National pavilions from dozens of countries will present alongside the main exhibition.

name: Yanshui Beehive Fireworks Festival
desc: One of the world's most dangerous festivals—thousands of bottle rockets fired directly into crowds of willing participants.
details: The Yanshui Beehive Fireworks is one of the world's most thrilling and dangerous festivals. Enormous racks of bottle rockets are ignited simultaneously, sending millions of fireworks horizontally into crowds of helmeted participants. The tradition began in the 1800s to ward off a devastating cholera plague. Known as 'Northern Fireworks, Southern Sky Lanterns' paired with Pingxi. Full protective gear is essential.

name: Hajj Season
desc: Annual Islamic pilgrimage to Mecca - one of the largest annual gatherings of people in the world.
details: One of the five pillars of Islam. Millions of Muslims from around the world converge on Mecca for the annual pilgrimage including rituals at Mina, Arafat, and Muzdalifah.

name: Sónar Barcelona
desc: Barcelona's cutting-edge festival at the intersection of art, music, and technology returns for its 33rd year with an eclectic lineup of global electronic artists.
details: Sónar celebrates the intersection of art, music, and technology. The 2026 lineup features Skepta, Nia Archives, Joy Orbison, and Sammy Virji. Sónar Week transforms Barcelona into an international hub of electronic music and culture, with partnerships including +RAIN Film Festival and OFFSónar. It's as much about creativity and new ideas as the music.

name: Boryeong Mud Festival
desc: South Korea's wildest summer festival where millions flock to Daecheon Beach for mud wrestling, mud slides, and mud baths.
details: The Boryeong Mud Festival is Korea's most internationally famous summer event, drawing visitors from around the world to Daecheon Beach. Mineral-rich mud from Boryeong's mud flats is used for mud wrestling, mud sliding, mud pools, and the mud prison experience. Music performances, fireworks, and beach parties continue into the night. Originally created to promote local cosmetics, it has become a cultural phenomenon.

name: Festa di Sant'Agata
desc: One of the world's largest religious festivals, with half a million Catanians following enormous candle-topped carriages through the streets in devotion to their patron saint.
details: The Festa di Sant'Agata is one of the world's largest religious celebrations, attracting up to a million participants over three days. Enormous candelore (carved wooden structures topped with candles) are carried through Catania's streets by devotees in traditional white sackcloth. The saint's relics are paraded in a silver fercolo (float). The atmosphere is intensely emotional — devotees weep, pray, and chant through the night.

name: Festa Nacional da Uva
desc: 35th celebration of grape harvest and Italian immigration with scenic-musical parades, grape distribution, and wine tastings at Mário Bernardino Ramos Event Park.
details: The 2026 edition celebrates 150 years of Italian immigration with theme "El Filó dela Mama: o grande coração" (The Mom's Filó: the great heart), emphasizing community spirit and Italian roots. Over 400 exhibitors expected to attract 700,000 visitors. 150 tons of grapes will be distributed throughout the festival. The scenic-musical parade combines theater, dance, live music, and thematic costumes telling the story of immigrants and Serra Gaúcha development. The Family Agriculture Pavilion features 85 agro-industries with high-value products including wines, juices, sausages, cheeses, jams, and cachaças.

name: Chicago Architecture Biennial (cab 6): Shift
desc: North America's largest international survey of contemporary architecture and design, exploring 'Architecture in Times of Radical Change.'
details: The sixth CAB features 100+ projects by global contributors at the Chicago Cultural Center and off-site locations. Free and open to the public. Founded in the city that gave birth to the skyscraper, CAB celebrates Chicago's architectural legacy while projecting its future. Theme SHIFT addresses radical change in the built environment.

name: Spring Equinox at Chichén Itzá
desc: Twice-yearly phenomenon where the setting sun creates a shadow serpent descending the Pyramid of Kukulcán.
details: On the spring equinox, the setting sun creates a shadow pattern on the El Castillo pyramid at Chichén Itzá that resembles a serpent (Kukulcán) descending the staircase. Thousands gather to witness this astronomical phenomenon, accompanied by cultural performances, traditional Maya ceremonies, and a festival atmosphere around the UNESCO World Heritage site.

name: Fiesta de Santo Tomás
desc: Intense patron-saint fiesta blending K'iche' Mayan rituals with Catholic traditions featuring masked dancers, colorful parades, fireworks, and ceremonies at the 16th-century church.
details: The Fiesta de Santo Tomás is held in honor of the patron saint of Chichicastenango, the apostle Thomas. This is one of Guatemala's most visually striking festivals, with activities centered on the Iglesia de Santo Tomás, a 16th-century church built on a pre-Columbian temple platform. The festival features colorful parades with masked dancers in vibrant costumes, elaborate fireworks, and a complete melding of K'iche' Mayan customs and Christian traditions. The church steps serve as venues for both Catholic ceremonies and Maya rituals involving incense offerings and prayers. Located 87 miles (140 km) from Guatemala City in the western highlands, Chichicastenango is easily accessible for travelers seeking authentic indigenous religious experiences.

name: Qoyllur Rit'i (Snow Star Pilgrimage)
desc: The "Snow Star" pilgrimage is one of Peru's most important indigenous religious ceremonies, drawing 100,000 annual pilgrims to glaciers beneath Mount Ausangate at over 4,600 meters elevation.
details: Qoyllur Rit'i, meaning "Snow Star" in Quechua, takes place high in the Sinakara Valley beneath the glaciers of Peru's most sacred mountain, Ausangate. Around 100,000 pilgrims annually travel to the sacred site, carrying images and participating in ceremonies that honor both Christ and the Apus (mountain spirits). The pilgrimage happens about a week before Corpus Christi and blends Catholic devotion with Andean spiritual traditions. Indigenous people celebrate the reappearance of the Pleiades constellation (known in Quechua as Qullqa or "Storehouse"), associated with the upcoming harvest and New Year. The Pleiades disappears from view in April and reappears in June, marking an important moment in the Andean calendar.

name: El Güegüense (San Sebastián Celebration)
desc: UNESCO Oral and Intangible Heritage performance featuring the historically significant El Güegüense play from 17th-century Nicaragua, blending Spanish and indigenous cultures with theater, dance, and music.
details: El Güegüense o Macho Ratón is a historical play from 17th-century Nicaragua and the country's first literary work, rooted in Nahuatl culture. It originated as a comedy in a colonial town under Spanish rule, where it cleverly mocked Spanish authorities and expressed resistance through humor. UNESCO recognized it as an "Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity." El Güegüense is a synthesis of Spanish and indigenous cultures combining theater, dance, and music, considered one of Latin America's most distinctive colonial-era expressions. The festival features 10-day celebrations from January 17-27 at Central Square and La Casa De Cultura in Diriamba. Plays are generally performed by eight main characters supported by dancers, with violins, guitars, and drums providing musical accompaniment. Costumes, wooden masks, hats, and other attributes differentiate the various characters, making it a colorful and energetic performance.

name: Qatar National Sports Day
desc: A unique public holiday dedicated to sport and wellbeing with community events and road races across Qatar.
details: Qatar's unique national holiday dedicated to physical activity and health, observed the second Tuesday of February. Events include community road races at Lusail Boulevard, fitness activities, and sporting events across the country. It's a distinctive Qatari celebration that reflects the country's commitment to active lifestyles.

name: Beltane Fire Festival
desc: Ancient Celtic fire festival on Calton Hill celebrating the arrival of summer with drumming, fire performance, and ritual.
details: This modern revival of the ancient Gaelic festival of Beltane takes place on Edinburgh's Calton Hill on the eve of May Day. Performers enact a dramatic ritual involving the May Queen, the Green Man, and elemental groups representing earth, air, fire, and water. Fire dancers, drummers, and acrobats create a visceral, pagan-inspired spectacle against the Edinburgh skyline.

name: Hakata Gion Yamakasa
desc: Explosive dawn race where teams sprint through Hakata carrying 1-ton decorated floats at breakneck speed.
details: Hakata Gion Yamakasa climaxes with the Oiyama on July 15th, when seven teams of men in traditional fundoshi race through the streets of Hakata carrying elaborately decorated kazariyama floats weighing about a ton—each at a frantic sprint. The 780-year-old festival at Kushida Shrine builds over two weeks of preparation. Massive 10-meter-tall display floats (kazariyama) are exhibited throughout Hakata.

name: Seb-i Arus / Whirling Dervishes Festival
desc: UNESCO-recognized spiritual ceremony honoring Sufi mystic Rumi with whirling dervish performances.
details: The Mevlana Festival in Konya commemorates the poet Rumi's death anniversary with sema (whirling dervish) ceremonies, Sufi music, conferences, and spiritual gatherings.

name: Carnaval Dominicano (Dominican Carnival)
desc: Dominican Republic's vibrant carnival with celebrations in La Vega, Santiago, and Santo Domingo, culminating in the National Carnival Parade.
details: La Vega Carnival celebrates over five centuries of tradition with famous Diablos Cojuelos (masked devils) and comparsas. Features the only mobile masks in the country with jaws that open and close showing teeth. Santiago Carnival showcases the iconic "lechones" characters (limping devils with pig-face masks, long snouts, and tall horns). The grand finale is the National Carnival Parade on March 1 at the emblematic Malecón of Santo Domingo. Celebrates Dominican culture, history, and community.

name: Frieze London & Frieze Masters
desc: Coinciding with Frieze London, focusing strictly on historical art through the late 20th century.
details: Frieze London focuses intensely on the contemporary avant-garde, while Frieze Masters offers a scholarly look at art from ancient times to the late 20th century. Together, they create a comprehensive, highly influential commercial and curatorial week.

name: Art Basel Miami Beach
desc: The Western Hemisphere's premier contemporary art fair, transforming Miami into a global art capital each December.
details: Art Basel Miami Beach brings together over 280 galleries from across the globe, showing works by established and emerging artists. The fair catalyzes Miami Art Week, with satellite fairs like Design Miami, NADA, and Untitled, plus massive installations in Wynwood and the Design District. The scene extends to exclusive parties, pop-ups, and cultural events throughout Greater Miami.

name: Igloofest
desc: An extreme, outdoor electronic music festival held in the freezing depths of the Canadian winter.
details: Igloofest is a uniquely Canadian experience - an outdoor electronic music festival held in sub-zero temperatures at the Old Port of Montreal. Thousands of bundled-up ravers dance to international DJs while surrounded by ice sculptures and warming stations. The festival includes a one-piece snowsuit contest.

name: Mt. Fuji Climbing Season Opening
desc: The opening of Japan's most sacred mountain for the annual climbing season.
details: The Mt. Fuji climbing season opens on July 1st with a ceremony at Fuji Sengen Shrine. Over 300,000 climbers attempt the summit during the two-month season. The pre-dawn climb to catch sunrise (goraiko) from the summit is one of Japan's most iconic experiences.

name: Mardi Gras / Carnival Season
desc: America's most iconic celebration of culture, music, and revelry with historic parades, masked balls, and street parties.
details: Starting with Twelfth Night on January 6, Carnival Season spans over six weeks culminating on Mardi Gras Day (Fat Tuesday). New Orleans draws over a million visitors to witness legendary krewes like Endymion, Orpheus, and Bacchus parade through the streets with massive floats. The celebration is rooted in French, Spanish, African, and Caribbean traditions with traditional balls, second-line parades, and King Cake parties throughout the season.

name: Noche de Rábanos (Night of the Radishes)
desc: Unique Oaxacan contest where artists carve elaborate sculptures from giant radishes displayed in the Zócalo.
details: On December 23rd, the plaza becomes an art gallery of intricately carved radish sculptures representing scenes from Oaxacan history, religion, and daily life. Artists work through the night of December 22nd into December 23rd to complete carving and assembly. Around 9 PM on December 23rd, winners are announced. The festival includes food vendors, performances, and celebrations of Oaxacan traditions. This centuries-old tradition uniquely combines agriculture, art, and culture.

name: Sundance Film Festival
desc: The premier independent film festival in North America, showcasing cutting-edge cinema from around the world.
details: Founded by Robert Redford, Sundance is the largest independent film festival in the United States and a major cultural event. Each year it premieres approximately 200 feature-length and short films from emerging and established filmmakers. The festival transforms Park City with screenings, panels, and celebrity sightings across multiple venues.

name: Qufu Confucius Cultural Festival
desc: Grand ceremony at the birthplace of Confucius featuring ancient rites and traditional music.
details: Qufu, birthplace of Confucius, hosts an annual ceremony on September 28th (Confucius's birthday) at the UNESCO-listed Temple of Confucius. The elaborate ritual includes ancient music, dance with feathered wands, and offerings. The ceremony follows protocols dating back over 2,000 years.

name: Carnival of Rio de Janeiro
desc: The world's largest carnival celebration featuring samba schools competing at the Sambódromo with elaborate floats, costumes, and choreography.
details: Rio Carnival is Brazil's most important cultural celebration, a five-day festival preceding Lent blending African, Portuguese, and Indigenous traditions. The Sambadrome hosts elite samba school competitions where 4,000+ performers per school parade with skyscraper-tall floats. Over 400 free street blocos (parties) take place across the city, from megablocos with celebrity performers to intimate neighborhood celebrations. Pre-carnival blocos begin in mid-January. The Champions Parade on Feb 21 features the top six schools.

name: Carnaval Dominicano
desc: The Dominican Republic's Independence Day carnival with colorful parades and costumes blending African, Spanish, and Taíno influences.
details: Carnaval Dominicano culminates on February 27th (the country's Independence Day) with elaborate parades and traditional celebrations. The carnival features traditional merengue and bachata music providing energy throughout the festivities.

name: Dragon Boat Festival (Taiwan)
desc: Thrilling dragon boat races across Taiwan's rivers with international teams competing in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
details: Taiwan's Dragon Boat Festival features competitive dragon boat races in Taipei (Keelung River), Kaohsiung (Love River), Lukang, and other cities. International teams increasingly participate. Traditional customs include eating zongzi (sticky rice dumplings), hanging mugwort, and wearing sachets. The Taipei International Dragon Boat Championship attracts elite teams from around the world.

name: Nowruz / Persian New Year 1405
desc: The ancient Persian New Year and UNESCO-recognized celebration of spring's arrival, observed by 300+ million people worldwide.
details: Nowruz (meaning 'new day') is the world's oldest secular holiday, celebrated for over 3,000 years. Beginning at the precise moment of the vernal equinox (05:19 UTC on March 20, 2026), celebrations span 13 days across Iran. Preparations include thorough spring cleaning (khaneh tekani), setting up the Haft-Seen table with seven symbolic items, Chaharshanbe Suri (fire-jumping), family gatherings, poetry readings, and sports events. The festival culminates with Sizdah Bedar (Nature Day) when families picnic outdoors. UNESCO recognizes Nowruz as an Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.

name: Asian Games 2026
desc: The 20th Asian Games—Asia's largest multi-sport event—returns to Japan for the first time in 32 years.
details: The 20th Asian Games will be held across Aichi Prefecture, centered in Nagoya. This is Asia's largest multi-sport event, organized by the Olympic Council of Asia, and the first time Japan has hosted since 1994 Hiroshima. Expect spectacular opening/closing ceremonies, cultural showcases, and competitions in 40+ sports with athletes from 45 nations.

name: Desert X AlUla 2026
desc: An open-air land art exhibition of 10 site-specific installations in AlUla's dramatic desert valleys under the theme 'Space Without Measure'.
details: Returning for its fourth edition, Desert X AlUla presents 10 new site-specific artworks by multigenerational Saudi and international artists scattered across Wadi AlFann and surrounding oasis zones. Curated by Wejdan Reda and Zoé Whitley under the theme 'Space Without Measure' (inspired by Kahlil Gibran), works use rammed earth, carved stone, and local materials. The exhibition is a stepping stone toward Wadi AlFann, a planned permanent open-air land art destination.

name: Aspendos International Opera and Ballet Festival
desc: Premier opera and ballet festival in the 2,000-year-old Aspendos Ancient Theatre with capacity for 12,000.
details: Organized since 1994 by the General Directorate of State Opera and Ballet. Perfect acoustics in the ancient theatre. World-class performances under the Mediterranean sky.

name: Athens & Epidaurus Festival
desc: Athens & Epidaurus Festival — music, opera, dance, and theater at the Odeon of Herodes Atticus beneath the Acropolis in Athens; drama and music at the Theater of Epidavros; some events now also held in January
details: The Athens Epidaurus Festival presents ancient Greek drama in the 2,400-year-old Theatre of Epidaurus with its perfect acoustics, alongside concerts at the Odeon of Herodes Atticus below the Acropolis.

name: Head of the Charles Regatta
desc: World's largest two-day rowing event on the Charles River with 11,000 athletes and 300,000 spectators.
details: The Head of the Charles Regatta transforms the banks of the Charles River between Boston and Cambridge into a massive outdoor celebration, with 11,000 athletes competing and 300,000 spectators picnicking, socializing, and cheering against a backdrop of peak fall foliage.

name: Busan Biennale 2026: Fluid Horizons
desc: The 13th edition examines how maritime perspectives shape contemporary understanding of connectivity, ecology, and global relations.
details: Titled 'Fluid Horizons: Art in an Age of Oceanic Thinking,' the 13th Busan Biennale explores oceanic metaphors and realities influencing artistic approaches to planetary interdependence. Emerged from the convergence of the Busan Youth Biennale (1983) and Sea Art Festival (1987), unified in 1998. New artistic directors announced.

name: Carnaval de Campeche
desc: One of Mexico's oldest carnivals with over 450 years of history, featuring traditional costumes, parades, and the famous "La Pintadera" tradition
details: The Carnival of Campeche is one of the oldest in the Americas, dating to colonial times. Parades, comparsas, and music fill the streets of this beautifully preserved UNESCO World Heritage walled city. The setting of colonial fortifications and pastel-colored buildings adds historical grandeur.

name: French Guiana Carnival (Carnaval de Guyane Française)
desc: One of the longest carnivals in the world, featuring traditional characters, masked balls, and vibrant street celebrations.
details: The festival runs for over six weeks with Sundays featuring street parades in Cayenne's center with afternoon celebrations. Saturdays showcase masked balls (called Paré-masqué) in Cayenne and surrounding areas. The "Face-à-face des Tololos" occurs on Friday, February 13, 2026, with the last Touloulou ball on Saturday, February 14, before Mardi Gras. Carnival Monday (February 16) and Carnival Tuesday/Fat Tuesday (February 17) are final festival days before Ash Wednesday. The festival features parades, masked balls, traditional characters, and various cultural celebrations throughout the extended carnival season.

name: Kanda Matsuri
desc: Tokyo's wildest Shinto festival where 100 portable shrines are paraded through Asakusa's streets with passionate intensity.
details: Sanja Matsuri is Asakusa's most famous festival, honoring the three founders of Sensoji Temple. Over 100 mikoshi (portable shrines) are vigorously paraded through the streets by teams of bearers who shake them to rouse the deity's spirit. The festival is known for its electric atmosphere, with taiko drumming, traditional music, and nearly 2 million spectators packing the narrow streets around Sensoji.

name: Corpus Christi
desc: Procession of fifteen patron saint images from different city parishes, blending Catholic ritual with Andean traditions and indigenous music.
details: One of Cusco's most important religious events begins on Wednesday evening with the traditional "entrada" (entrance) of saints and virgins from their home parishes. Each image travels in procession accompanied by faithful devotees, musicians, dancers, and organizers through Cusco's historic streets until gathering near the Church of San Pedro and entering the Basilica Cathedral in Plaza de Armas on Thursday. While the central day is Thursday, festivities extend several days including the octava (eighth day celebration) one week later. Admission is free and open to the public.

name: Midsummer (Midsommar)
desc: Sweden's most cherished summer tradition of dancing around flower-decorated maypoles, singing folk songs, drinking schnapps, and feasting on pickled herring under the midnight sun.
details: Midsommar is second only to Christmas as Sweden's most important holiday. Swedes take to the countryside wearing flower crowns, raise and dance around decorated maypoles, eat pickled herring with new potatoes and dill, drink schnapps with traditional songs, and enjoy fresh strawberries. In northern Sweden, the midnight sun never sets. The celebration embodies Swedish culture's connection to nature, light, and community.

name: 665th Kirkpinar Oil Wrestling Festival
desc: World's oldest ongoing sporting event where wrestlers compete in traditional Turkish oil wrestling dating back to 1360.
details: UNESCO-recognized annual tournament where pehlivans compete for the Golden Belt. Contestants wear leather kispets and coat bodies in olive oil. Festive fairs with music, grilled lamb, and dances.

name: Micareta de Feira de Santana
desc: Off-season carnival (Micareta) featuring traditional blocos afros, afoxés, samba groups, reggae, and indigenous groups with government cultural support.
details: The State Department of Culture (SecultBA) and Department for Racial Equality Promotion (Sepromi) launched Record Call (Edital Ouro Negro) allocating R$17 million for carnival programming in Salvador and interior cities including Feira de Santana. The initiative strengthens afro block participation, afoxés, samba, reggae, and indigenous groups. Registration free through online form by October 15. Featured entities include Feira Axé, Ogunje, Brasil Meu Samba, Estrela do Oriente, Unidos da Rua Nova, Nativos de Santana, and Sorriso Negro.

name: Tết Nguyên Đán (Vietnamese Lunar New Year)
desc: Vietnam's most significant cultural event with family reunions, vibrant flower markets, lion dances, and massive fireworks displays.
details: Tet is the soul of Vietnamese culture — a time when the entire nation returns home for family reunions. Streets transform with peach blossoms in the North and Ochna flowers in the South. Hanoi's flower markets, Ho Chi Minh City's fireworks, and Hoi An's lantern-lit streets create unforgettable atmospheres. Lion dances, temple visits, and elaborate feasts mark the celebration.

name: Harbin Ice and Snow Festival
desc: The world's largest ice and snow festival featuring massive illuminated ice castles and sculptures spanning 1.2 million square meters.
details: The Harbin Ice Festival transforms the city into a frozen wonderland. The Ice and Snow World features massive illuminated ice buildings carved from blocks pulled from the Songhua River. The Snow Sculpture Art Expo at Sun Island showcases intricate snow art. At night, LED-lit ice structures create a surreal neon cityscape. Activities include ice swimming, dog sledding, and skiing. The 42nd edition opened January 5, 2026.

name: Kenka Matsuri (Imadate)
desc: Dramatic 'fighting festival' where ornate portable shrines are crashed together in fierce competition.
details: Imadate Kenka Matsuri in Echizen features teams violently crashing their elaborately decorated mikoshi (portable shrines) into each other. The collisions represent the deities competing for supremacy. The aggressive energy and ornate craftsmanship of the floats create a thrilling contrast. Multiple 'fighting festivals' exist across Japan, each with its own character.

name: Carnaval de Huejotzingo
desc: Centuries-old carnival with elaborate battalion costumes reenacting historic Puebla battles, declared Cultural Heritage in 1997.
details: 158th edition with approximately 70,000 dancers participating in four days of celebration preceding Ash Wednesday. Battalions dressed in luxurious, striking traditional costumes reenact three historic episodes: Battle of May 5, 1862 (Mexican Army vs. French forces); abduction of Corregidor's daughter; and story of Agustín Lorenzo (colonial bandit defending peasants). UNESCO recognition and "Hecho en México" (Made in Mexico) seal received February 17, 2026 from federal government. Streets transformed with excitement and traditional pageantry.

name: Stagecoach Festival
desc: The largest country music festival in the world, held at the Empire Polo Club in the Coachella Valley.
details: Billed as 'California's Country Music Festival,' Stagecoach brings together the biggest names in country, Americana, and roots music across multiple stages. The festival includes line dancing, western-themed experiences, and Guy Fieri's Stagecoach Smokehouse. Its desert setting and party atmosphere make it a unique country music experience.

name: 54th Istanbul Music Festival
desc: Month-long celebration of tulips throughout Istanbul's parks with millions of flowers transforming the city.
details: Theme 'Here & Now' with venues including historic churches, outdoor spaces, and the Grand Bazaar. Features Wiener Symphoniker, three world premieres, and a new Relaxed Concert series for neurodivergent audiences.

name: Dai Water Splashing Festival
desc: Epic water-fight New Year celebration of the Dai people—the wetter you get, the more blessed you are.
details: The Water Splashing Festival is the Dai ethnic minority's New Year celebration and Xishuangbanna's biggest event. For three days, entire communities take to the streets for massive water fights—splashing symbolizes washing away bad luck and bestowing blessings. Additional festivities include dragon boat races on the Lancang River, sand art, peacock dances, lantern floating, and temple ceremonies. The main celebration centers on Jinghong city.

name: 6th Kochi-Muziris Biennale: For the Time Being
desc: India's first and South Asia's longest-running contemporary art biennale, curated by Nikhil Chopra as a living ecosystem.
details: The 6th Kochi-Muziris Biennale features 66 artist projects from 25+ countries across Fort Kochi over 110 days. Curated by Nikhil Chopra with HH Art Spaces, it envisions the Biennale as a living ecosystem rather than a singular event. Moves away from centralized exhibition models toward process as methodology.

name: Koyasan Candle Festival
desc: 100,000 candles illuminate the sacred Okunoin cemetery—one of Japan's most spiritual places.
details: Mount Koya's Candle Festival lights approximately 100,000 candles along the path through Okunoin cemetery, the resting place of Kobo Daishi. The candlelight flickering among ancient cedar trees and thousands of moss-covered stone monuments creates an extraordinarily spiritual atmosphere.

name: Aoi Matsuri (Hollyhock Festival)
desc: Kyoto's oldest festival featuring a grand procession of 500+ participants in Heian-era court costumes.
details: The Aoi Matsuri dates back to the 6th century and is one of Kyoto's three great festivals. A stately procession of over 500 people dressed in authentic Heian-period (794-1185) aristocratic costumes walks from the Imperial Palace to Shimogamo and Kamigamo shrines. The central figure, the Saio-dai priestess, wears a junihitoe (twelve-layered kimono) weighing about 30 kilograms.

name: Gion Matsuri
desc: Japan's most famous month-long festival featuring a procession of massive yamaboko floats weighing up to 12 tons through Kyoto's streets.
details: Gion Matsuri at Yasaka Shrine is among Japan's three great festivals and has been held since 869. The highlight is the Yamaboko Junko procession (July 17 and 24), where 33 towering, elaborately decorated floats—some weighing up to 12 tons—are pulled through Kyoto's streets. The preceding Yoiyama evenings feature atmospheric street markets and illuminated floats. Many floats are designated UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage.

name: Carnaval de La Ceiba (La Ceiba Carnival)
desc: Honduras's largest and most energetic festival honoring Saint Isidore the Laborer, featuring two weeks of celebration with religious observances, artisan markets, parades, and neighborhood carnavalitos.
details: The Feria Isidra and La Ceiba Carnival take place each May in the Caribbean port city of La Ceiba and together form Honduras's largest annual festival, attracting over half a million people each year. The celebrations honor Saint Isidore the Laborer, the city's patron saint, and typically unfold over about two weeks, culminating in a large-scale street carnival. The Feria Isidra dates back to 1917 and functions as La Ceiba's traditional city fair. Early activities include religious observances tied to Saint Isidore's feast day on May 15, alongside artisan markets, cultural performances, sports events, and coronation of the fair's queen. As the month progresses, neighborhoods host their own carnavalitos—smaller street festivals with music, food vendors, and dancing that build momentum across the city. The main carnival is held on the final Saturday of celebrations (May 23, 2026). Often described as Honduras's signature festival, the Feria Isidra and Gran Carnival draw large domestic and regional crowds and mark May as La Ceiba's busiest and most energetic month.

name: Ganesh Chaturthi
desc: Mumbai's spectacular 10-day celebration of Lord Ganesha with massive decorated idols and euphoric processions to the sea.
details: During Ganesh Chaturthi, elaborately decorated pandals (temporary structures) house massive clay idols of Lord Ganesha throughout Mumbai. Communities compete to create the most impressive displays. The festival culminates in Visarjan — a massive procession carrying the idols through the streets to be immersed in the sea, accompanied by drumming, dancing, and fireworks.

name: Hanal Pixán (Yucatán Day of the Dead)
desc: Unique Yucatecan Maya tradition honoring the dead, distinct from mainland Día de Muertos with special altars and foods.
details: "Hanal Pixán" means "food of the souls" in Maya. Celebrated October 31–November 2 (also visible activities October 29–30). Features elaborate ofrendas (altars) with white tablecloths, jacaras (gourds for food/drink), white candles, colored candles for children, cempasuchil and coxcomb flowers, and green wooden crosses representing ceiba tree (important in Maya cosmology). October 31 dedicated to deceased children. Special dish: PIB (Mucbipollo)—1.5 kg tamale cooked in underground oven with corn, chicken, pork, beans wrapped in banana leaves. Paseo de las Ánimas: evening parade with hundreds dressed as souls walking from cemetery to downtown Mérida—highlight of celebration. Family altars strictly follow ritual: no photos until year after death; food untouched until day after.

name: Mexico City Art Week 2026 (Zona Maco)
desc: Latin America's premier contemporary art fair with 228 galleries from 26 countries
details: Zona Maco (main fair), Feria Material/Material Art Fair (12th edition), Salón ACME #13. Material Monday (Feb 2, 4-9 PM) launches week with simultaneous gallery openings across city. Salón ACME (Feb 5-8 at Proyectos Públicos) highlights emerging creators with Puebla state artists.

name: EDC Mexico 2026
desc: World's largest electronic dance music festival with art, rides, performers, and carnival atmosphere
details: Insomniac's flagship festival with massive stages, pyrotechnics, lasers, art installations, carnival rides, and performers. Over 200 DJs across stages playing house, techno, trance, dubstep, and hardstyle. One of the largest EDM festivals in Latin America.

name: Infiorata di Noto
desc: Sicily's Baroque gem hosts a spectacular flower carpet festival where artists create huge pictures from flower petals along the Via Corrado Nicolaci.
details: The Via Corrado Nicolaci (122 metres long) is split into 16 sections, each becoming a canvas for artists to create incredible pictures using flowers. All artwork is linked by a common theme. Set against Noto's stunning UNESCO-listed Baroque architecture, the festival is a visual feast. The tradition complements similar events in Spello and Genzano.

name: Inti Raymi - Otavalo & Regional Celebrations
desc: Ancient indigenous celebration of the sun god with spiritual purification rituals, communal dance, and harvest thanksgiving.
details: Inti Raymi is celebrated with midnight ritual cleansing at sacred Peguche Waterfall (Otavalo), dawn ceremonies with offerings to the sun and Pachamama, and spiritual rituals led by yachaks (shamans). Celebrations include communal dance, shared traditional food, and cultural expression. In Otavalo, celebrations last multiple days with a parade through Plaza de Ponchos and live music and dancing. The festival allows indigenous Ecuadorians to reconnect with suppressed identity and celebrate cultural heritage.

name: Umbria Jazz
desc: One of Europe's most important jazz festivals, filling Perugia's medieval streets and piazzas with world-class jazz, blues, soul, and funk for ten days.
details: Umbria Jazz transforms the medieval hilltop city of Perugia into a jazz lover's paradise. The main arena hosts headline acts while free concerts fill the city's stunning piazzas, churches, and theaters. Since 1973, it has grown into one of the world's top jazz festivals, attracting both legendary names and exciting newcomers. The combination of world-class music and Umbrian food, wine, and architecture is irresistible.

name: Pingxi Sky Lantern Festival
desc: One of the world's most magical festivals—thousands of glowing sky lanterns released into the night sky.
details: The Pingxi Sky Lantern Festival, named by Discovery Channel as one of the world's best festivals, features mass releases of 100,000-200,000 glowing rice-paper lanterns into the night sky. The tradition dates to 1821 when Chinese settlers used lanterns to signal safety after bandit attacks. Two main events in 2026: February 27 at Pingxi Junior School and March 3 at Shifen Square. Participants write wishes on lanterns before releasing them.

name: Cavalhadas (Pirenópolis, Goiás)
desc: 200-year tradition (since 1826) featuring horseback reenactments of medieval Christian-Moorish battles during Pentecost with masked figures called Curucucús.
details: Cavalhadas represents the oldest continuous staged reenactment in Brazil depicting ancient Iberian Peninsula medieval conflicts. Moorish and Christian knights in armor clash on horseback while masked Curucucús (figures in colorful clothes, gloves, and boots) make pranks and jokes throughout. The three-day event occurs in late afternoon on Pentecost Sunday through Tuesday with government of Goiás allocating R$5 million for the 2026 Cavalhadas Circuit touring 16 municipalities May-September. The tradition symbolizes Portuguese and Spanish cultural legacy in Brazil.

name: Mawazine Festival (Rhythms of the World)
desc: One of the world's largest music festivals attracting millions, blending global superstars with Arab and African artists.
details: Launched in 2001 under King Mohammed VI's direction, Mawazine draws 2.5-3.75 million attendees across stages in Rabat and Salé. Past headliners include The Weeknd, Marshmello, and Ellie Goulding alongside Moroccan and Arab stars. Free open-air stages and ticketed concerts make it both massive and accessible. The festival transforms Morocco's political capital into a huge open-air stage for nine days.

name: Reykjavik Culture Night
desc: Reykjavík's largest city festival with free events from morning to evening and a spectacular fireworks finale.
details: Culture Night is Reykjavík's biggest annual celebration, with free events colouring city life from morning to evening. Museums, galleries, shops, and gardens host performances, exhibitions, and activities. The day culminates in a spectacular fireworks display. It coincides with the Reykjavík Marathon.

name: Fiesta Nacional de la Nieve - Bariloche
desc: Seven-day winter celebration featuring snow sports, queen election, torch processions, and lumberjack competitions.
details: Activities include regional textile contests, logger and lumberjack competitions, waiter races, national and international performances, float parades, torch processions, and the Bajada de Antorchas (Torch Descent). Queen of the Snow election is central event. Concludes with fireworks. Held at Cerro Catedral, Civic Center, and Gymnasium No. 1.

name: Festas do Apóstolo Santiago
desc: Festas do Apóstolo — St. James Festival), Santiago de Compostela (arts, free concerts, street theater, fireworks on July 24 and 31, culminates with carnival on July 25 — St. James Day / Diá de Santiago and Galicia Day; closures on July 25 i
details: The end-point of the Camino de Santiago pilgrimage celebrates its patron saint with two weeks of arts, free concerts, street theater, and fireworks on July 24 and 31. The festival culminates on July 25 — St. James Day and Galicia Day — with a carnival atmosphere. Pilgrims who've walked hundreds of kilometers mingle with locals in what is both a sacred and festive occasion.

name: Carnival of São Paulo
desc: São Paulo's vibrant carnival with 627 street blocos and Sambódromo parades featuring major samba schools competing with elaborate productions.
details: The São Paulo carnival is decentralized with blocos in neighborhoods like Vila Madalena, Centro, Pinheiros, and Faria Lima. Featured performers include Ivete Sangalo heading Quem Pede, Pede bloco for the first time, and Agrada Gregos promoting diversity and inclusion. Mega-bloco circuits feature pop, axé, funk, and eletrônico rhythms. Free buses operate on carnival Sundays. Over 600 registered street blocos offer accessible entertainment.

name: Tobago Carnival
desc: Tobago's carnival celebration occurring at a different time of year from Trinidad, with soca, calypso, and traditional performances.
details: The National Carnival celebrations in Tobago feature the island's vibrant music, dance, and cultural traditions. Takes place during the island's carnival period allowing locals and visitors to experience Tobago's unique carnival traditions and cultural expressions.

name: Sendai Tanabata Matsuri
desc: Japan's most famous Star Festival celebration with thousands of elaborate bamboo streamers decorating the city center.
details: Tanabata celebrates the romantic legend of star-crossed lovers Orihime and Hikoboshi who can only meet once a year. Sendai's version is the most spectacular, with enormous handmade paper streamers and decorations hanging from bamboo along the shopping arcades. Visitors write wishes on tanzaku paper strips and hang them on bamboo. The festival includes parades, performances, and fireworks.

name: Palio di Siena (August)
desc: The heart-stopping medieval horse race around Siena's Piazza del Campo — 90 seconds of pure adrenaline preceded by days of pageantry, rivalry, and centuries of neighborhood passion.
details: The Palio is not just a horse race — it is an explosion of passion, pageantry, and centuries-old rivalry between Siena's 17 contrade (neighborhoods). Held twice yearly in the shell-shaped Piazza del Campo, the race lasts only 90 seconds but is preceded by days of historical parades, flag-throwing, church blessings, and intense neighborhood celebrations. The emotional intensity — with spectators crying, embracing, and screaming — is unlike anything else in Europe.

name: Singapore Biennale 2025: Pure Intention
desc: The eighth Singapore Biennale spreads 100+ works across five neighborhoods as a signature event of Singapore's 60th anniversary (SG60).
details: Curated by Duncan Bass, Hsu Fang-Tze, Ong Puay Khim, and Selene Yap, featuring 80+ artists. Unlike previous editions, works spread beyond SAM across five neighborhoods. Part of SG60 citywide celebrations. Explores how art illuminates complexities of space, identity, and transformation in Singapore's changing urban environment.

name: Vienna Christmas Markets
desc: Vienna's enchanting Christmas markets fill the city's grand imperial squares with traditional crafts, punch, and Advent magic beneath the backdrop of palaces and cathedrals.
details: Multiple Christmas markets transform Vienna into a winter wonderland. The main market at Rathausplatz features hundreds of stalls, an ice rink, and spectacular lighting along the City Hall facade. Other markets at Schönbrunn Palace, Belvedere, and Spittelberg each have distinct character. Traditional Punsch, Maroni (roasted chestnuts), and handcrafted ornaments abound. Vienna's imperial architecture provides an unmatched backdrop.

name: Viljandi Folk Music Festival
desc: The biggest folk festival in Scandinavia and the Baltics, set in the atmospheric medieval castle ruins of Viljandi.
details: This four-day celebration transforms the tranquil town of Viljandi into a vibrant hub of folk music, with nine stages and around 60 artists from around the world set among the scenic castle hills and overlooking Lake Viljandi. The 2026 theme is 'To Each Their Own Instrument.' Founded in 1993, it welcomes 27,000+ visits and features performances, workshops, a handicraft yard, and a lively fair.

name: Boomtown Fair
desc: An intensely immersive, theatrically driven music festival resembling a massive, interactive film set.
details: Boomtown is renowned for its mind-bending stage designs and deep, overarching narrative that attendees participate in. It heavily features drum and bass, reggae, punk, and underground dance music.

name: Vardavar (Water Festival)
desc: Armenia's exciting water-splashing festival where everyone douses strangers, friends, and passing cars.
details: Originally honoring ancient goddess Astghik (love and water), now celebrated by Armenian Apostolic Church. People pour water on friends, strangers, passing cars. Public squares, streets, parks transform into playful water zones.

name: Yokote Kamakura Snow Festival
desc: Enchanting 450-year-old tradition where hundreds of igloo-like snow houses (kamakura) line the streets.
details: The Yokote Kamakura Festival is a beloved Akita tradition where hundreds of kamakura (snow houses) are built throughout the city. Children sit inside the kamakura around a small altar, offering amazake (sweet rice wine) and mochi to passersby. At night, the miniature kamakura along the river create a magical glowing landscape.

name: Qingming Festival (Tomb-Sweeping Day)
desc: Solemn yet beautiful spring festival for honoring ancestors by sweeping graves and enjoying spring outings.
details: Qingming combines ancestor veneration with celebration of spring. Families visit ancestral graves to sweep, clean, and make offerings of food and paper money. Beyond the solemn rituals, it is also a time for spring outings (taqing), kite flying, and enjoying the blossoming landscape. Many cities organize kite festivals alongside the observance.

name: Bangkok Art Biennale (BAB)
desc: The fifth edition of Bangkok's major art biennale explores 'Angels and Mara' under Artistic Director Apinan Poshyananda.
details: The Bangkok Art Biennale returns for its fifth edition themed 'Angels and Mara,' organized by the Bangkok Art Biennale Foundation with Thai Beverage. The BAB has grown rapidly since its 2018 debut, placing contemporary art across Bangkok's temples, public spaces, and cultural institutions. Public and private sector support enables free access to most exhibition sites.

name: Electric Castle
desc: Castle-domain festival mixing music and arts; report cited 274K attendance (2024) and 2026 dates.
details: Electric Castle at the Banffy Castle ruins near Cluj-Napoca combines electronic music, art installations, and the magical Transylvanian setting for a unique festival experience.

name: Sziget Festival
desc: Budapest's 'Island of Freedom' — one of Europe's largest and most diverse festivals, combining music, art, theater, and circus on an island in the Danube.
details:
olicies.

name: Festival de Tango
desc: Showcases tango culture through competitions, milongas (dance halls), performances, and master classes with legendary tango dancers.
details: Multiple tango events include the Argentina Tango Salon Festival (Jan 7-12) featuring milongas, shows, and classes. The Tango Journey to Buenos Aires (Aug 11-25) offers daily lessons with top Argentine maestros and nightly milonga visits. CITA (Congreso Internacional de Tango Argentino) also offers an all-inclusive admission pack. Free entrance for public events throughout the city.

name: Buenos Aires Tango Festival & World Cup
desc: Annual spring jazz festival with performances on 20+ stages throughout Buenos Aires, featuring local and international jazz musicians.
details: The Festival y Mundial de Tango is the world's premier tango event. Two weeks of milongas, open-air performances, classes, and the Tango World Championship. Free outdoor milongas in plazas invite anyone to dance under stars. Celebrates Buenos Aires' greatest cultural export in the neighborhoods where tango was born.

name: São João de Campina Grande (Festa Junina)
desc: The world's largest São João celebration featuring traditional June festival culture, quadrilha dancing, live music, and typical northeastern gastronomy.
details: Campina Grande's São João is recognized as the biggest festival of its kind in the world, transforming the city with 33 days of festivities at Parque do Povo. The venue features a scenic reproduction of historic city buildings with over 200 stalls offering regional dishes including forró music performances, quadrilha competitions, and traditional dances celebrating Saint John's Day.

name: Chichibu Night Festival
desc: One of Japan's three great float festivals with massive illuminated floats and winter fireworks.
details: The Chichibu Yomatsuri is one of Japan's three great float festivals alongside Gion and Takayama. Six ornate floats weighing up to 20 tons are pulled up a steep slope by hundreds of men, accompanied by taiko drumming and 7,000+ fireworks. The climax is the dramatic ascent of Dan-no-zaka slope. Designated a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage.

name: Cologne Carnival (Kölner Karneval)
desc: Germany's wildest carnival transforms Cologne into a week-long street party of satirical floats, costumes, and revelry culminating in the legendary Rosenmontag parade.
details: Known as the 'Fifth Season,' Cologne Carnival has medieval roots and blends political satire, humor, and Rhineland spirit. The Weiberfastnacht (Women's Carnival Day) on February 12 kicks things off when women symbolically take over the city. The 8km Rosenmontag (Rose Monday) parade features elaborate satirical floats mocking politicians. Street parties fill the Altstadt and Südstadt neighborhoods with the joyful cry of 'Kölle Alaaf!'

name: Thousand Camel Festival
desc: Unique Gobi Desert festival celebrating the endangered Bactrian camel with races, polo, and cultural events.
details: The 29th annual Thousand Camel Festival promotes breeding of two-humped Bactrian camels and preserves traditional livestock practices. Features camel racing (1,108 camels set Guinness World Record in 2016 on 15km course), camel polo, herding skills competitions, decorated camel parades, traditional Mongolian music and dance. Over 8,000 visitors attend, including 200+ foreign tourists. Camel herders from 60+ soums bring 1,000+ camels.

name: Creamfields
desc: The UK's premier electronic music festival, with massive production values and headline DJs across multiple stage designs.
details: Creamfields has been at the forefront of UK electronic music culture for over two decades. The festival features world-renowned DJs across elaborately designed stages with cutting-edge production. Located in Cheshire, it draws electronic music fans from across Europe for an intense weekend of dance music.

name: Edinburgh International Book Festival
desc: The curated, world-class arts festival featuring top opera, classical music, ballet, and theater companies from around the world — Edinburgh's original festival since 1947.
details: Unlike the open-access Fringe, the Edinburgh International Festival is carefully curated, bringing together some of the best opera, classical music, ballet, and theater from around the world. Top orchestras, dance companies, and theater groups perform shows that challenge and inspire. Alongside the Fringe and Military Tattoo, it forms a cultural trifecta that makes August in Edinburgh utterly extraordinary.

name: Mystic Festival
desc: Poland's largest metal festival at the historic Gdańsk Shipyard with 90+ bands.
details:
pen'er Festival** | Gdynia, Poland | Jul 1-4, 2026 | Indie, Rock, Hip-Hop | \~100,000+ |
| **Pohoda Festival** | Trenčín, Slovakia | Jul 8-11, 2026 | Multi-genre, Alternative | \~30,000 \- 80,000 |
| **INmusic Festival** | Zagreb, Croatia | Jun 22-24, 2026 | Rock, Indie | \~80,000+ |
| **Donauinselfest** | Vienna, Austria | Jul 3-5, 2026 | Multi-genre, Local focus | \~2.5 Million |

### **Sziget Festival: The Reclama

name: Celtic Connections
desc: One of Europe's most beloved winter music festivals, transforming Glasgow into a hub of folk, roots, world, and contemporary music with hundreds of events.
details: Celtic Connections transforms Glasgow into a vibrant hub of folk, roots, world, and contemporary music every January. Over three weeks, hundreds of events showcase established performers, rising stars, and surprising collaborations. Everything from headline concerts in grand theatres to intimate late-night sessions in traditional pubs. The festival fosters genuine connection between artists and audiences.

name: Festival de Cinema de Gramado
desc: Brazil's most traditional and longest-running film festival featuring national and international cinema, documentaries, and shorts.
details: The Festival de Cinema de Gramado takes place at the Palácio dos Festivais in the charming mountain town of Gramado. The 2026 edition set a record with 1,378 film submissions (44% increase), including features, shorts, and documentaries. The festival is curated by film critics and industry professionals, transforming Gramado into an open-air red carpet welcoming stars, filmmakers, critics, and cinema lovers from Brazil and Latin America.

name: Carnaval de Gualeguaychú - Carnaval del País
desc: Argentina's largest open-air carnival spectacle featuring elaborate comparsas (parade groups) with over 270 participants each, 12 monumental floats, and percussion-driven performances.
details: The 2026 edition honors Roberto "Toto" Arakaki and Néstor Lapalma for their contributions to carnival development. Four historic comparsas (Marí Marí, Papelitos, O'Bahía, Ará Yeví) perform with electrifying percussion bands and original compositions. Performance dates include January 3, 10, 17, 24, 31, and February 7, 14, 15, 16, 21, 28. Tickets range from $25,000 to $66,000.

name: Carnaval de La Habana (Havana Carnival)
desc: The second-largest festival in Cuba, featuring spectacular displays of music, dancing, and colorful costumes along the famous Malecón promenade.
details: Features parades along the Malecón promenade during several consecutive weekends in July and August. Beyond parades, includes numerous concerts, dances, Kids Carnival, and traditional markets with handcrafted products and street food. Streets are transformed with dancing-couples, posters, music, congas, masks, puppets, paintings, and photographs. Kiosks line the streets selling traditional items.

name: Jeonju International Film Festival
desc: A major Asian film festival fiercely dedicated to independent, experimental, and arthouse cinema.
details: The 27th Jeonju International Film Festival promotes the spirit of independence and experimentalism in cinema. Held in the beautiful traditional hanok village city of Jeonju, it has become recognized globally as a barometer of current film movements. The festival screens hundreds of independent films and offers a uniquely Korean cultural experience in the old town's traditional architecture.

name: Riddu Riđđu
desc: International indigenous festival celebrating Sámi culture and indigenous peoples from around the world.
details: This unique festival in Arctic Norway celebrates indigenous culture through music, art, film, and workshops. Founded by Sámi youth in 1991, it has grown into a major international gathering for indigenous peoples. Set against stunning northern Norwegian landscapes, the festival combines traditional joik singing with world music, and offers workshops in traditional crafts and cultural exchange.

name: Documenta 16
desc: One of the world's most important contemporary art exhibitions, held every five years in Kassel since 1955.
details: Directed by Naomi Beckwith, the lead-up to documenta involves intense global research and preliminary programming. The 2026 phase is crucial for stabilizing the institution after previous controversies and establishing its new artistic direction.

name: Gozan Okuribi (Daimonji Fire Festival)
desc: Massive bonfires in the shape of kanji characters lit on five mountains surrounding Kyoto to guide spirits.
details: The Gozan Okuribi is the dramatic climax of Obon in Kyoto. At 8pm, the famous Dai (大) character is ignited on Higashiyama, followed by four other characters/shapes on surrounding mountains at five-minute intervals. The fires are visible across the city and are best viewed from the banks of the Kamogawa River or rooftop venues. The event symbolizes sending ancestral spirits back to the afterlife.

name: 18th Biennale de Lyon
desc: A major European contemporary art exhibition known for its vast, multi-venue installations.
details: The 18th Biennale de Lyon opens September 19, 2026. As one of Europe's most established recurring contemporary art exhibitions, it has been a fixture of the French cultural calendar since 1991. Specific curatorial details and artist lists for this edition are still being announced.

name: Summer Sonic Festival
desc: Japan's premier urban rock and pop music festival held simultaneously in Tokyo and Osaka.
details: Summer Sonic is Japan's other major music festival, held simultaneously at Makuhari Messe (Tokyo area) and Maishima (Osaka). The festival features a mix of international megastars and Japanese artists across rock, pop, hip-hop, and electronic genres. Unlike outdoor-focused Fuji Rock, Summer Sonic includes large indoor arenas, making it weather-proof.

name: Feria de Manizales
desc: Colombia's most important festival celebrating coffee culture with 300+ activities including bullfighting, parades, concerts, and International Coffee Queen pageant.
details: 69th edition expects 400,000+ visitors. Key dates: Pregón de Feria (Inauguration), Desfile de Carretas del Rocío (traditional flower cart parade), Festival eliminations, and Superconcierto at Palogrande Stadium featuring Carlos Vives, Silvestre Dangond, Blessd, Giovanni Ayala, Calibre 50, Hamilton. Traditional activities: bullfighting, Fonda de la 65, parades, cultural presentations. International Coffee Reign pageant features ~24 candidates from coffee-producing/consuming nations competing for the title.

name: Salone del Mobile Milano
desc: The largest, most important furniture and design trade fair in the world.
details: Anchoring Milan Design Week, the Salone is an unrelenting, networking marathon at Fiera Milano. In 2026, it introduces 'Salone Raritas', a new collectible design pavilion conceived by Formafantasma, bridging industrial design with fine art.

name: EPCOT International Food & Wine Festival
desc: Disney's culinary celebration with 25+ Global Marketplaces, celebrity chef events, and the Eat to the Beat concert series.
details: The Epcot International Food & Wine Festival features over 25 Global Marketplace kiosks around World Showcase offering international cuisine and beverages. Celebrity chef demonstrations, premium dining events, and the Eat to the Beat concert series complement the culinary exploration.

name: Carnaval de Panamá (National Carnival)
desc: Four-day national carnival celebration with culecos (street parties), elaborate parades, concerts, and festivities throughout Panama with Volumen Caribe festival in the capital.
details: The Carnavales 2026 in Panama will be celebrated from Saturday, February 14 to Tuesday, February 17, with the Tuesday declared an official public holiday. Communities, municipalities, and authorities organize desfiles (parades), culecos (water and street celebrations), and cultural events that convert carnaval into one of Panama's most important festivities on the national calendar. The Alcaldía de Panamá emitted a decree establishing regulations and schedules for the Festival Carnavalístico Volumen Caribe 2026, held February 13-17 on the Cinta Costera and Avenida Balboa. The festival atmosphere is energetic with traditional costumes, live music, dancing in the streets, and community celebrations across multiple locations.

name: Fête de la Musique (France)
desc: Every street corner in France becomes an open-air concert stage on the summer solstice, with free music from amateur and professional musicians playing in every city.
details: On the longest day of the year, streets across France turn into open-air stages with free concerts in every city, big or small. From jazz quartets in Parisian courtyards to rock bands in Marseille plazas, anyone can perform anywhere. The concept has spread worldwide since its 1982 founding, but France remains the spiritual home. A uniquely democratic celebration of music in all its forms.

name: Phuket Vegetarian Festival
desc: One of Thailand's most visually striking festivals with extreme devotional practices, street processions, and Chinese religious ceremonies.
details: The Nine Emperor Gods Festival features devotees performing remarkable acts of devotion including firewalking and body mortification. Chinese shrines throughout Phuket host elaborate ceremonies, processions, and rituals. The entire city adopts a vegetarian diet, and Chinese-Thai street food stalls line the streets with specialized festival dishes.

name: Carnaval de Puno (Puno Carnival)
desc: Following the Fiesta de la Candelaria, Puno's carnival features large comparsas, street parades, water games, paint games, and a grand corso with floats and dancers.
details: The Carnaval of Juliaca in Puno takes place from February 14-16, with activities extending until February 28. Celebrations include large comparsas, street parades, live music, water, paint and talcum powder games, and a grand corso with floats and dancers. The celebration concludes with the symbolic burial of Ño Carnavalón, marking the end of carnival season. Carnival activities are more community-focused, often spread across neighborhoods and rural areas near Lake Titicaca, including traditional dances, Andean music ensembles, family gatherings, and shared meals. Rituals connect to agriculture and gratitude to the land, reflecting strong Aymara cultural traditions. The carnival follows the Fiesta de la Candelaria and represents a parallel celebration of Puno's vibrant cultural identity.

name: Navruz (Persian New Year)
desc: Central Asia's most important spring festival celebrating the New Year with feasts, music, and merry-making across the Silk Road cities.
details: Ancient celebration (3,000+ years old) marking spring equinox and new year. Parks and squares host music performances, folk festivals, concerts by folk-ethnographic groups, horse riders, and athletic competitions. Traditional sumalak (taffy-like treat) is cooked communally the night before. Month-long March celebration with book fairs, special TV programs, and festive meals. UNESCO-recognized heritage.

name: Carnaval de Santa Cruz (Santa Cruz Carnival)
desc: One of Bolivia's most anticipated celebrations, featuring weeks of precarnaval activities, queen coronations, 267 comparsas, seven hours of continuous spectacle at the Grande Corso Cruceño.
details: The Carnaval Santa Cruz 2026 features an extended celebration. Precarnavaleras (pre-carnival events) begin Saturday, January 10 with the 1st precarnavalera dedicated to Colonial themes. January 17 features the 2nd Republican precarnavalera, January 24 features Street Carnival, and January 31 features the 4th precarnavalera: Carnival of the Future, combining tradition and innovation. February begins with February 1 Bandeao Carnavalero, followed by the Queen of Old Carnival coronation on February 5 and the main Carnival Queen coronation on February 7, with an Infant Corso on February 8. The central event occurs Saturday, February 14, with the expected Grande Corso Cruceño at the Cambódromo, where comparsas, queens, and folk groups display carnival joy and creativity. The event features 267 comparsas in seven hours (17:30 until approximately 1:30 AM). Traditional three days of "mojazón" (water games) occur Sunday February 15, Monday 16, and Tuesday 17. The Asociación Cruceña de Comparsas Carnavaleras (ACCC) released the official agenda.

name: Carnival of Santa Cruz de Tenerife
desc: Europe's answer to Rio de Janeiro, this Canary Islands carnival draws 250,000+ visitors with spectacular queen galas, Latin rhythms, and sunshine-drenched parades.
details: Declared a Fiesta of International Tourist Interest in 1980, Tenerife Carnival is widely regarded as Europe's most vibrant carnival and second-largest in the world after Rio. The 2026 theme is 'Ritmos Latinos' (Latin Rhythms). Features include the Queen Gala coronation, massive costumed parades, samba schools, daytime street carnivals in plazas, and the Burial of the Sardine closing ceremony. February weather averages 21°C with sunshine.

name: Lollapalooza Brasil 2026
desc: A major international music festival featuring 71 acts across multiple genres including pop, rock, hip-hop, and electronic music.
details: Lollapalooza Brasil brings world-class artists across rock, pop, hip-hop, electronic, and other genres. Headliners confirmed include Sabrina Carpenter, Tyler the Creator, and Chappell Roan.
